title: 109_hr5332
content: The Act may be cited as the "Teen Pregnancy Prevention, Responsibility, and Opportunity Act of 2006". Congress finds that the United States has the highest teen-pregnancy rate and teen birth rate in the western industrialized world, costing the country billions annually. About 1 in 3 young women in the US becomes pregnant before the age of 20, leading to serious consequences such as high school dropout, poverty, and increased likelihood of children ending up in prison or becoming teen parents themselves. Teens growing up in disadvantaged circumstances are particularly at risk. Teens in disadvantaged circumstances more likely to engage in risky behavior and have a child during adolescence. Strong emotional attachments to parents delay sexual activity. Lack of communication with parents is a common reason for teen pregnancy. Unsupervised hours increase likelihood of teens having sex. After-school programs reduce risky behavior. After-school programs reduce teen risky behavior by providing activities that offer alternatives to sex, such as sports for girls, leading to delayed sexual activity and fewer partners. These programs also help prevent teen pregnancy by promoting good decision-making skills, offering health education, and providing positive role models in a supervised setting. Many teens express regret about having sex too early. SEC. 3. EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR PREVENTING TEEN PREGNANCIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may grant funds to local educational agencies, public health agencies, and nonprofit entities for projects educating on preventing teen pregnancies. Preference is given to projects in communities with high teen pregnancy rates. Grants are contingent on providing age-appropriate pregnancy prevention information. The project on pregnancy prevention will prioritize preventing teen pregnancies by encouraging teens to delay sexual activity, providing educational services, educating young men and women about parenting responsibilities, helping parents communicate with teens about sexuality, and teaching responsible decision-making. Matching funds are available for project costs. Matching funds are required for the project, with the applicant needing to provide non-Federal contributions of at least 25% of the project costs. These contributions can be in cash or in kind, excluding any assistance or subsidies from the Federal Government. The grant recipient must maintain non-Federal expenditures for project activities at a level equal to or higher than the previous fiscal year to be eligible for a grant. The Secretary will establish evaluation criteria for projects, and applicants must agree to conduct evaluations and submit reports to the Secretary. The Secretary will establish evaluation criteria for projects, and applicants must agree to conduct evaluations and submit reports. A report must be submitted to Congress by October 1, 2011, describing the success of projects in reducing teen pregnancies. The section defines "age-appropriate" and "factually and medically accurate and complete" in relation to pregnancy prevention information for children and adolescents based on their cognitive, emotional, and behavioral development. It emphasizes the importance of using verified and scientifically supported information in peer-reviewed journals. The term "local educational agency" is defined in relation to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. An authorization of $20,000,000 is provided for each fiscal year from 2007 to 2011 for carrying out the section. SEC. 4. REAUTHORIZATION OF CERTAIN AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to increase funding for the 21st Century Community Learning Centers and the Carol M. White Physical Education Program. Additionally, additional funding is authorized for the Federal TRIO Programs. The Federal TRIO Programs and GEARUP funding levels are amended to increase to $883,000,000 and $325,000,000 respectively for fiscal year 2007 and the following 5 years. SEC. 5. DEMONSTRATION GRANTS FOR TEEN PREGNANCY PREVENTION AND AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS. The Secretary may provide grants to public or nonprofit entities to demonstrate innovative approaches to prevent teen pregnancies, including teen-driven prevention methods, realistic simulations of pregnancy consequences, and effective parent-child communication programs. Grants require matching funds from the applicant. The Secretary may provide grants for innovative teen pregnancy prevention projects, requiring non-Federal contributions of at least 25% of the costs. Contributions can be in cash or in kind, excluding Federal assistance. Projects must meet evaluation criteria set by the Secretary to be eligible for grants. The applicant must agree to conduct project evaluations, submit reports to the Secretary, and provide a plan for evaluations in the grant application. The application must meet specific criteria and include necessary agreements and information as determined by the Secretary. A report to Congress is required by October 1, 2011. The Secretary must report to Congress by October 1, 2011, on the success of projects in reducing teen pregnancies. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2007 to 2011 for this purpose.
